# Incomplete-action verbs

## Introduction

So far we have learned how to use completed-action verbs with the different doer pronoun suffixes. In this chapter we will learn how to use incomplete-action verbs. These verbs are used when the action of the verb is on-going or has not yet begun.

Completed-action verbs' doer pronouns are added as suffixes to the verb. In contrast, incomplete-action verbs' doer pronouns are prefixes, while the ends of the verbs are also modified to denote the number of the doer, i.e., whether the doer is singular, dual or plural. Another difference from completed-action verbs is that incomplete-action verbs have states (u-state, a-state, etc.), just like nouns.

As an example, the completed action verb for the root [كتب]{.arroot} is [كَتَبَ]{.ar} [kataba]{.trn} "he wrote" for the non-participator masculine singular. The incomplete-verb
